bibl.title: Letter from Charles Inman and Elizabeth Fitzpatrick to James E. Watson, November 22, 1926

div1.p: Representatives of the New York Association of Biology Teachers petition Sen. Watson to seek Congressional action on pensions for Kissinger and widows of yellow fever commission participants.

div1.head: Letter from Charles Inman and Elizabeth Fitzpatrick to James E. Watson, November 22, 1926
div1.opener:
THE NEW YORK ASSOCIATION OF BIOLOGY TEACHERS
November 22, 1926
Hon. James E. Watson,
Senator from Indiana.
Honorable Sir:-
div1.p:
Do you know the story in recent American history that
appeals most strongly to the high school boy or girl of today--the
future citizens of our country? It is the story of the Yellow Fever
Commission, consisting of Major Walter Reed, Dr. Jesse Lazear,
Dr. Carroll and Dr. Aristides Agramonte, appointed after the
Spanish American War by President McKinley. This marvellous story
has been taught during the past quarter of a century by every
bioloby teacher in the country.

There came in the course of these experiments a call for
volunteers to submit themselves to the bites of mosquitos infected
by yellow fever patients. John R. Kissinger was the first to respond.
When he refused to accept any monetary compensation, Major Reed
touched his cap and said, “I salute you.” Major Reed, in his
official report to the United States Government (see Senate
Document No. 822, p. 96) said, “In my Judgment this exhibition of
moral courage has never been surpassed in the annals of the Army of
the United States.”

No one can learn that this hero, Kissinger, has been a
helpless invalid for years without feeling a distinct shock. He has
been and in wholly incapacitated for work; his only income is a
Government annuity of $100 a month; and for years his wife has
taken in washing to pay for their support and for doctor's bills.
The Kissingers are at present living in a small house in Andrews,
Huntington County, Indiana. They have not the necessary income to
provide the necessities for even reasonable comfort. How could they
on an income of only $100 a month?

The American people are much too generous to wish such treat-
ment of their heroes. We know that the reason for such treatment
is the fact that this condition has not been brought to the
attention of Congressmen individually. We are bringing the matter
to your attention, asking you to look after it personally, because
it seems to us that it will seem to you not only your personal duty,
but also your personal privilege, since this hero lives in your
state.

While Congress is looking after the Kissinger case, should
not adequate provision also be made for the widows of Major Reed,
Dr. Lazear, and Dr. Carroll, who are living in straitened circumstances
because their husbands gabe their lives in this cause? It goes
without saying that we teachers will take more joy in telling this
story and our boys and girls will feel more pride in their Country
when they know these heroes are made comfortable while they live.
An annuity of $250 per month for each of the four families would
be sufficient. We respectfully urge you to present a bill in the
Senate providing for this expenditure. While you are doing it,
won't you provide for Mrs. Kissinger for the rest of her life, in
case Mr. Kissinger should die first?

closer.signed:
Charles G. Inman, President
Elizabeth T. Fitzpatrick, Sec'y
